comments.commentBody: The Bell Curve is right - another Obama and Hillary regime change atrocity
There type of thing has been nonstop since WWI ended by both parties.
You are misinformed. You might read some history before making such a misguided comment.
This is the NYT. I think you clicked on the wrong bookmark. This is not The Drudge Report.

"The United States helped birth this nation, building ministries, training soldiers, pumping in more than $11 billion since 2005."

Why? What business does the US have in this nation? What national interest of the US was served?

I sincerely hope that President Trump stops the US from continually getting into everyone's business all over the world, and then owning problems that have nothing to do with America or Americans.

Maybe it is our $11B that is fueling this war.
Baron, a closer look at the article would be of benefit to you, there is oil there. And  at least some of Trumps billionaire plutocrats cabinet members have investments there.

Economic interests are put before humanitarian needs. South Sudan produces almost all oil of former Sudan. This keeps the war active in the best agricultural regions, it last since South Sudan was founded. The population is of no importance for the war parties, its just for the control of oil revenues.
South Sudan population growth approaching 4% annually while famine approaches. In response Trump cuts off family planning aid leading to more not fewer abortions.

Perhaps if so many in this country were more concerned with opening their heart to what's happening in Africa and less concerned with empowering a handful of billionaires to privatize, deregulate, break unions, make money in energy, and build up the world’s largest military we could truly make America greater.

comments.commentBody:
" There was so much hope when the country was formed."
Hope is all over the place--fishing holes, race tracks, everywhere.
It means nothing.

comments.userLocation: from The Hall of Great  Achievement
comments.commentBody: No matter the Act 1, or Act 2, Act 3 is always the same:murder and mayhem.
Looks like a waste of money. Lesson learned: stay out of other countries especially if there is no reliable government. Giving money only enriches the ruling class.

This is a tale told in Europe for the past 500 years ago until 1945 as the tribes (French, German, Spanish, Swedes, Danes, Austrians, English, Italians) fought for control of that continent resulting in millions dead over the span of centuries. This is Nationalism, Modernization and Globalization sweeping into the previously pre-modern areas of the world and causing the same level of havoc and destruction. Colonialism is just a temporary by product of these forces. Our only hope is some degree of internal recognition by these "tribal" leaders that conflict is inherently counter-productive combined with an external coercive force forcing them to behave and limit their corruption. The West has to be willing to force these tribal leaders to cooperate with each other all the while providing them some incentive to cooperate. Or we can sit back and watch them repeat the same bloody process the Europeans went through until a peace was forced upon them by the US.
To John Crosby: You actually believe this claptrap?

There is a sick twist to all of this. The problem is that facts don't always represent truth! especially when dialectics run rampant in the modern world. Africa, as it is today, is not what it is simply because of self neglect. But because of external forces that systematically feed upon it, denies it the ability to challenge for its future, while the mechanisms of divide et impera keeps it a self perpetuating killing field.

However, someone has forgotten that ALL is energy and that spheres have circuits!

Amazing that most commentators completely forget that the west split south sudan for oil. Where is the "save darfur" outrage now?

The $11B "aid" most likely went to payoff corrupt locals to allow western companies in and for south sudan to spend on "infrastructure" built by western companies. So most of this $11B is probably in the hands of oil, infra and security companies. Rest easy, your tax money was well spent.
(Thanks, DL. Me like language.)
Put it down and come back to it, that always helps.
Mr. Romig, I want to express my appreciation for a well-written, insightful, thoughtful, and informative article.  Thank you.

So the moral of the story seems to be that there needs to be a social compact on how a region's assets are to be used. If the compact is merely let the assets be taken by the whims of individual,clan or others who could care less about the eventual outcome, then the endgame is dreadful. It is pretty clear that humanity has yet to evolve past the hunter gatherer mentality and mother nature will have to school us all on the consequences of that world view. Hardly a difference between this and drill baby drill or our ever expanding population. That's why we pay to watch Star wars episodes. They simply build a new planet out there to house our ever expanding reproductive needs. Somehow I don't think it's going to turn out that way.

The truely sad part of this is that there is nothing unique about it. The crime of the rivers and their sand deposits was that they were not producing income for some group -- that there were devastating consequences afterwards was not their problem. Too many burdensome regulations, I think is the current mantra.

I am resident of South India and I thank you very much for highlighting this important issue. Even our national media has so far shied away from projecting this atrocity in a big way.
We have corrupt politicians and bureaucrats on the one hand and neo-corporate houses, that promise heaven on earth, on the other. When these two join hands, the result is destruction of nature.
It is not just rivers that we have lost, we have lost plenty of forest lands too. Almost all of India is naked without greenery. Plenty and plenty of species have been wiped out. The government is just not bothered about all these destruction.
India is known world wide as an agricultural country. Without water, there is no agriculture. When rivers are destroyed, I wonder where come we will get water. No dams are being constructed to save water. Our rivers are also not linked. Already there is water scarcity in many parts of India.
Unless Indian Government realizes that there is no substitute to nature, in the given situation, future of India is highly dangerous.

This is such a sad story. it so closely tracks what I have observed when traveling in India. How can sense ever come in such a chaotic society? Where could one begin? This is not to say anything negative about the many wonderful and intelligent people in India.
This is why India will never be a great nation.
The New Yorker has done a number of very interesting pieces on water in the western US
You can bribe a judge in India, they are one of highest paid civil servants.
The question is how are developing countries gonna satisfy the short of homes? There are no cheap alternative.
We are dumb species.we going to kill our self for greed.

I witness the same destruction in Bangladesh every time I visit: The mighty Padma and Brahmaputra (Ganges by other name) are shadows of what they used to be, with round-the-clock sand-mining disrupting the natural flow and destroying the rivers, all in the name of progress. You see the hideous urban jungles lining the banks and laborers groaning under their heavy load of sand and iron and brick, building sand castles for others while earning a pittance, completely under the whip of the local mafia. 'Riverine' Bangladesh is turning into a desert, particularly in the north. An environmental, and human, tragedy of enormous proportion, indeed!
The World’s Disappearing Sand: https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/23/opinion/the-worlds-disappearing-sand....
